Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Impacts of Local Oceanographic Processes on Adelie Penguin Foraging Ecology Over Palmer Deep
Award.AbstractNarration:
The application of innovative ocean observing and animal telemetry technology over Palmer Deep (Western Antarctic Peninsula; WAP) is leading to new understanding, and also to many new questions related to polar ecosystem processes and their control by bio-physical interactions in the polar environment. This multi-platform field study will investigate the impact of coastal physical processes (e.g. tides, currents, upwelling events, sea-ice) on Adélie penguin foraging ecology in the vicinity of Palmer Deep, off Anvers Island, WAP. Guided by real-time surface convergence and divergences based on remotely sensed surface current maps derived from a coastal network of High Frequency Radars (HFRs), a multidisciplinary research team will adaptively sample the distribution of phytoplankton and zooplankton, which influence Adélie penguin foraging ecology, to understand how local oceanographic processes structure the ecosystem.

Core educational objectives of this proposal are to increase awareness and
understanding of (i) global climate change, (ii) the unique WAP ecosystem, (iii) innovative methods and technologies used by the researchers, and (iv) careers in ocean sciences, through interactive interviews with scientists, students, and technicians, during the field work. These activities will be directed towards instructional programming for K-16 students and their teachers. Researchers and educators will conduct formative and summative evaluation to improve the educational program and measure its impacts respectively.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the last 60 years, the Western Antarctic Peninsula (WAP) has experienced profound, rapid environmental changes, including a 6 degree Centigrade increase in mid-winter surface air temperatures (greater than 5 times the global average), increased heat content of seawater, and retreat and melting of glaciers.  The population sizes of true Antarctic species such as Adelie penguins are declining, but in contrast the population sizes of sub-Antarctic species such as gentoo penguins are increasing as these warmer-climate species migrate southward.  The arrival of gentoo penguins in former Adelie penguin territory has potentially created new foraging competition that raises important questions regarding the impact that climate migration may have on foraging competition, and the persistence and function of critical biological hotspots.

Intellectual Merit:  The environmental cues that influence foraging behavior are not well understood in penguins, but are critically important to understand how the environment can drive species distributions in the context of climate variability and change.  Our study examined the environmental cues that two penguin species (Adelie and gentoo) use to locate food.  By examining predator foraging behavior at the individual level, we were able to conduct a unique analysis of this important marine ecological hotspot, and illustrate the role that fine scale environmental cues have on top predator foraging behavior and their prey fields.  We found that Adelie and gentoo penguins used different environmental cues in the same foraging habitats.  This suggests that potential competition due to climate-induced shifts in species composition may be mediated by the differences in foraging behavior of each species, and that environmental mechanisms that maintain top predators in these hotspots are species-specific.  

Our study also specifically addressed the mechanisms that underlie the enhanced biological productivity associated with the Palmer Deep Canyon biological hotspot.  We found that surface circulation is likely responsible for delivering phytoplankton biomass produced elsewhere into the canyon, much like a conveyor belt.  This continual replentishment of food feeds local Antarctic krill communities, which in turn supports numerous top predators.  This discovery contradicts the previously proposed mechanisms of local biological production in this particular hotspot, and empahsizes the importance of surface circulation and the winds that drive it.

Broader Impacts:  Our project included a very strong broader impacts component that reached a wide audience.  We worded with 25 educators and their students from middle and high schools in New York and New Jersey.  The goal was for students to conduct their own research concurrently with our field season and making use of our data.  We held an educator workshop in August 2014, introducing our study to the educators who would then take it to their classrooms.  The students followed our field season in 2014-2015 online, reading and commenting on our daily blogs (28 posts, 249 photos, 495 comments, 52,261 page views with 7,877 individual users) and downloading our data.  In January 2015, the teachers and joined the field team remotely for a series of video teleconferences from Antarctica.  In April 2015, we hosted a one-day science symposium in which the students presented results of their research and were able to interact with some of the research team.  In addition, we conducted two 1 hour video teleconference with the general public through the Cornell Lab of Ornithology.  These are available as archived videos for download and currently these have been viewed 5000 times.

CONVERGE education and outreach efforts served as the prototype for NSF funded Polar Interdisciplinary Coordinated Education (ICE, PLR 1440435 and OPP 1525635).  The Science Investigator program (Sci-I) was modeled after CONVERGE and served 48 educators and more than 3,000 students in inquiry based learning.  The CONVERGE model has shown statistical significance in building a) student engagement in science -- defined as persistence, interest and curiosity in STEM; b) contributions to student identity, defined as describing themselves as having qualities or charactersitics of a scientist (think of themselves as scientists); and c) understanding of the Process of Science, defined as complex, iterative and non-linear procedure, involving observations, exploration, testing communication and application.

Through integrating educators and students into the research mission and exposing them to the actual process of doing science and for themselves, educators and students increased their understanding of the authentic process of science and use of real-world data.  Key drivers of the sucess of this project for educators and students were being part of a science mission, through the expedition journal and VTCs, as well as actually doing an open-ended science investigation as part of an authentic process more than just a school assignment.  An indication of the broad scale success of this project was the change in educators' approach to teaching the process of doing science to be more active and student-led, as well as how the students grew to see themselves as contributing scientists and as active drivers of their learning process.
